This article explains why even after getting vaccinated against COVID-19, it is still important to wear masks for a while. Vaccines can prevent people from getting sick, but they may not prevent someone from carrying the virus and spreading it to others without showing symptoms. This is called being an asymptomatic carrier. Until more people are vaccinated and the spread of the virus is under control, wearing masks can help prevent the spread of COVID-19.

The article discusses the different regulatory approaches used by various countries to approve Covid-19 vaccines, and how this has led to a competition between independent and politicized models of regulation. The author argues that while some countries have prioritized scientific rigor and transparency in their approval processes, others have allowed political considerations to influence their decisions. This has led to concerns about the safety and efficacy of certain vaccines, and highlights the need for a more coordinated and transparent global approach to vaccine regulation.
